com.topcoder.util.file
Class DocumentGeneratorCommand

java.lang.Object
  com.topcoder.util.file.DocumentGeneratorCommand

public class DocumentGeneratorCommand
extends java.lang.Object

The DocumentGeneratorCommand class is the command line class used to execute document generation. This class loads configurations via Configuration Persistence component, and creates an instance of DocumentGenerator via DocumentGeneratorFactory. It executes document generation via the created DocumentGenerator instance. Command Line Utility is used to process command line arguments and related stuff.

Thread-safety: This class is thread-safe since it's immutable.

see the method documentation of main for command line usage of this class.

Version:
3.0
Author:
gniuxiao, TCSDEVELOPER

Field Detail

DEFAULT_CONFIGURATION_FILE

public static final java.lang.String DEFAULT_CONFIGURATION_FILE
The default configuration file. It's used to load configuration by Configuration Persistence if the configuration file is not provided by command line argument.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

DEFAULT_NAMESPACE

public static final java.lang.String DEFAULT_NAMESPACE
The default configuration namespace. It's used to load ConfigurationObject by Configuration Persistence if the configuration namespace is not provided by command line argument.

Method Detail

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] params)

Command line parameters.

Generate document.

  • [-s[ource] #source_id#] -t[emplate] #template_name# -x[ml] #xml_data_file# [-o[ut] output_txt_file] [-c[onfig] #configuration_file#] [-n[amespace] #namespace#]

Add template:

  • [-s[ource] #source_id#] -t[emplate] #template_name# -a[dd] #template_file# [-c[onfig] #configuration_file#] [-n[amespace] #namespace#]

Remove template:

  • [-s[ource] #source_id#] -t[emplate] #template_name# -r[emove] [-c[onfig] #configuration_file#] [-n[amespace] #namespace#]

  1. -s[ource] #source_id# The template source identifier to look the templates into (the sources are configured in the config file). If it is missing then the default template file will be used (see the sample config file).
  2. -t[emplate] #template_name# The name of template to be used. The name is specific to the template source. For database sources it is an actual name. For file sources it is the name of the file. For future implementations it might mean other things (file name for CVS sources, name for LDAP).
  3. -x[ml] #xml_data_file# The XML file with field data for the template.
  4. -o[ut] #output_file# The output text file. If it is missing then the output will be written to the standard output.
  5. -a[dd] #template_file# The template file to add to the template source. It will overwrite existing templates with the given name.
  6. -r[emove] Removes the template from the template source.
  7. -c[onfig] #configuration_file# The configuration file to use, DEFAULT_CONFIGURATION_FILE will be used if it's not provided
  8. -n[amespace] #namespace# The namespace to load ConfigurationObject, DEFAULT_NAMESPACE will be used if it's not provided

Note: As it is indicated above by the [] paranthesis, either shortcuts (-s, -t, -x, -o, a, r, c, n) or full names (-source, -template, -xml, -out, -add, -remove, -config, -namespace) can be used.

Note: All exceptions that occur while using the API will be caught and meaningful messages will be displayed.

Parameters:
params - the command line arguments
Since:
3.0
